vr.pr: ˈthē-ə-tər, ˈthēə-, oftenest in Southern ˈthē-ˌā- also thē-ˈā-

entry.et: Middle English theatre, from Middle French, from Latin theatrum, from Greek theatron, from theasthai to view, from thea act of seeing; akin to Greek thauma miracle

def.dt: :an outdoor structure for dramatic performances or spectacles in ancient Greece and Rome
:a building or area for dramatic performances
:a building or area for showing motion pictures
:a place or sphere of enactment of usually significant events or action the theater of public life
:a place rising by steps or gradations a woody theater of stateliest view John Milton
:a room often with rising tiers of seats for assemblies (as for lectures or surgical demonstrations)
:dramatic literature :plays
:dramatic representation as an art or profession :drama
:dramatic or theatrical quality or effectiveness
:spectacle 1a
:entertainment in the form of a dramatic or diverting situation or series of events their public feud made for good theater
:theater of operations
:of, relating to, or appropriate for use in a theater of operations theater nuclear weapons
:a theater in which the stage is located in the center of the auditorium called also arena theater
:the style or method of staging plays in a theater-in-the-round
:the part of a theater of war in which active combat operations are conducted
:theater that seeks to represent the absurdity of human existence in a meaningless universe by bizarre or fantastic means
:the entire land, sea, and air area that is or may become involved directly in war operations
:theater-in-the-round
:a theater that specializes in the presentation of art films
:a restaurant in which a play is presented after the meal is over
:street theater
